title: 105_hr4656
content: The Act may be cited as the "City of North Las Vegas Public Land Acquisition Act of 1998". The Congress finds that the Bureau of Land Management owns a large parcel of land near private property in North Las Vegas, Nevada, which is difficult to manage and should be sold or exchanged for responsible development. The rapid growth of the Las Vegas metropolitan area is impacting surrounding national recreation areas. The purpose of this Act is to orderly dispose of certain Federal lands in North Las Vegas, Nevada, and acquire environmentally sensitive lands in Nevada, including the Mountains National Recreation Area surrounding Las Vegas Valley. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, "unit of local government" refers to the City of North Las Vegas in Nevada, "Agreement" refers to the Interim Cooperative Management Agreement between the Bureau of Land Management and Clark County, "special account" refers to the account in the Treasury established under section 4(e)(1)(C), and "Recreation and Public Purposes Act" refers to the Act authorizing acquisition of public lands for recreational purposes. The term "regional governmental entity" includes the Southern Nevada Water Authority, the Regional Flood Control District, and the Clark County Sanitation District. SEC. 4. DISPOSAL AND EXCHANGE. The Secretary is authorized to dispose of lands in Clark County, Nevada, subject to valid existing rights, as depicted on a specific map. The map is available for public inspection. The Secretary may offer lands for sale or exchange in Nevada, but the State or local government can elect to obtain the lands for public purposes under the Recreation and Public Purposes Act. Additionally, rights-of-way can be issued to local or regional governmental entities upon application. The Secretary can issue right-of-way grants on Federal lands in Clark County, Nevada for water-related facilities and flood control management, with grants being valid indefinitely and fees waived. The right-of-way grants issued under this paragraph in Clark County, Nevada do not require payment of rental or cost recovery fees. Federal lands identified for disposal are withdrawn from mining laws and mineral leasing laws until the Secretary terminates the withdrawal or the lands are patented. Proceeds from land sales include 5% for the State of Nevada's general education program and 10% for the Southern Nevada Water Authority for water treatment. The Southern Nevada Water Authority will receive payments for water treatment and infrastructure in Clark County, Nevada. Amounts will be deposited in a special account for the Secretary's use without further appropriation. Land exchanges will involve direct payments based on fair market value of Federal lands. The special account will receive payments for environmentally sensitive land acquisition in Nevada, with priority in Clark County, and for capital improvements in various national areas. The special account will receive payments for land acquisition and capital improvements in Clark County, Nevada, including conservation areas, habitat conservation plans, parks, trails, and natural areas. Coordination with the Secretary of the Bureau of Land Management is required for the use of the special account. The special account, established for land acquisition and capital improvements in Clark County, Nevada, will involve coordination with the Secretary of Agriculture, the State of Nevada, local governments, and interested parties to ensure accountability. A limitation of 25% of the funds available to the Secretary can be used for specific purposes in any fiscal year. All funds deposited in the special account will earn interest based on the current market yield of US obligations. The interest earned on funds deposited in the special account for land acquisition and capital improvements in Clark County, Nevada will be added to the principal and used according to specified provisions. SEC. 5. ACQUISITIONS. The subsection defines "environmentally sensitive land" as land that promotes preservation of various values and public enjoyment. It also includes enhancing recreational opportunities, public access, better management of public land, and serving the public interest. The Secretary may acquire environmentally sensitive land with proceeds from a special account after consultation with relevant parties. Consent of the landowner is required, and funds from the special account can be used in conjunction with other available funds. Before acquisition, consultation with the State of Nevada, local governments, planning and regulatory agencies, and interested parties is necessary. The Secretary can acquire environmentally sensitive land using funds from a special account after consulting with relevant parties. Consent of the landowner is needed, and the acquired land becomes part of designated areas without further action by the Secretary or Secretary of Agriculture. The Secretary can acquire environmentally sensitive land using funds from a special account after consulting with relevant parties. The acquired land must be managed in accordance with all applicable laws and regulations. The fair market value of the land to be acquired shall be determined according to federal laws and regulations, without considering the presence of threatened or endangered species. Amendments are made to the Payments in Lieu of Taxes section of the United States Code. Amendments are made to the Payments in Lieu of Taxes section of the United States Code by adding subparagraph (H) for land acquired under the Southern Nevada Public Land Management Act of 1997 by the Secretary of the Interior or Secretary of Agriculture. The Secretary, with the Secretary of Agriculture, submits an annual report on transactions to the Senate and House committees. Additionally, there are amendments to the Payments in Lieu of Taxes section for land acquired under the Southern Nevada Public Land Management Act. The Secretary may transfer the reversionary interest in lands in Clark County, Nevada, subject to a lease or patent under the Recreation and Public Purposes Act, to non-Federal lands of equal value upon request by a grantee. Excess fair market value received by the State of Nevada or a local government shall be paid to the Secretary. The Secretary may transfer the reversionary interest in lands in Clark County, Nevada to non-Federal lands of equal value upon request by a grantee. The fair market value of lands to be transferred may be based on a statement of value prepared by a qualified appraiser. Land selected by the grantee shall be subject to the terms and conditions, uses, and acreage limitations of the lease or patent to which the lands transferred were subject under the Recreation and Public Purposes Act.
